title.narrative: FAO/ECOWAS , 2019-2023 Global Transformation of Forests for People and Climate
FAO/ECOWAS, 2019-2023 Global Transformation of Forests for People and Climate

description.narrative:
FAO har frågade Sida om bidrag om 75 000 000 SEK för implementeringen av "Global transformation of Forests for People and Climate: A Focus on West Africa" under perioden 2019 - 2023.
Insatsen bygger vidare på FAO's pågående arbete i ECOWAS regionen. Insatsen har tre prioriterade fokusområden, dvs; 1) kunskap om skogsekosystemets dynamik; 2) Skogs- och markrelaterade lagar, strategier och policys på subregional nivå; 3) demonestration och spridning av kunskap om hållbar skogs- och markanvändning. Fokusområdena har identifierats i ECOWAS s.k konvergensplan godkänd av ECOWAS medlemsstater. De förväntade övergripande resultaten omfattar samtliga ECOWAS medlemsstater, där specifika insatser och aktiviteter avser ett urval av länder med liknande ekologiska förutsättningar och utmaningar.
ECOWAS är en nyckelpartner för genomförandet av projektet tillsammans med statliga myndigheter för skog- och klimat, civilsamhället med inriktning på hållbar skogs- och markanvändning, urbefolkning och lokala samhällen bosatta i eller nära skogsområden, samt universitet och forskningsinstitut. På begäran av ECOWAS så kommer ett MoU ingås för att formalisera samarbetet mellan Sverige och den nämnda organisationen. Ett separat insatsavtal kommer att ingås mellan Sida och FAO som bygger på ramavtalet som tecknades i 2017. En dialog kommer under projektets sex månaders inledningsfas att föras med olika intressenter för ytterligare informationsinhämtning.

FAO has asked Sida for funding of 75,000,000 SEK to carry out the project named "Global transformation of Forests for People and Climate: A Focus on West Africa " during the period 2019 – 2023.
The intervention builds on FAO’s existing support in the ECOWAS region and targets on three priority focus areas, namely Knowledge of the state of forest ecosystem dynamics; Forest and land related laws, policies and strategies at the sub-regional level; and Demonstration and dissemination of sustainable forest and land use practices. These focus areas were identified in the Convergence Plan endorsed by member states of ECOWAS. The expected overall results encompass all ECOWAS member countries while specific outputs and activities refer to a selection of countries that show similar ecological characteristics and challenges.
ECOWAS is a key partner for implementation of the intervention together with forestry and environmental units in government agencies, NGOs and CSOs concerned with forests and land use, Indigenous peoples and local communities who reside in or near forested areas, and academia and research institutions. Based on the request from ECOWAS so as to formally report on the contribution of Sweden in the region, ECOWAS and Sweden will sign MoU in support of this project. Sida and FAO will sign a separate Contribution Agreement, under the existing FAO-SIDA Framework Agreement, signed in 2017. During the inception phase of the project, outstanding issues will be clarified and agreed upon between the partners.

The overall objective of the contribution is to strengthen decision-making on forests and land management, and to strengthen capacity at a sub-regional level through ECOWAS and other sub-regional partners to implement elements of the regionally agreed plan called the Convergence Plan. Achieving this objective will positively contribute to the livelihoods and climate change resilience thus contributes to the achievement of the SDGs and the Paris Agreement, identified as the broader impact. In addition, identifying lessons learned and best practice will contribute to a longer-term impact through sharing in other sub-regions and globally. This intervention builds on FAO’s existing support in the region and targets three priority focus areas of the Convergence Plan, around which all the project outputs are clustered (Knowledge of the state of forest ecosystem dynamics; Forest and land related laws, policies and strategies at the sub-regional level; and Demonstration and dissemination of sustainable forest and land use practices). The expected overall results encompass all ECOWAS member countries while specific outputs and activities refer to a selection of countries that show similar ecological characteristics and challenges.

description.narrative: The year 2019 was the first year of a new 5-year Swedish support for FAO/ECOWAS, which was started with a six months inception phase. The cooperation has been smooth, with interesting discussions including organizing a Steering Committee (SC) meeting conducted in September 2019 to formally conclude the inception phase. The SC meeting was attended by representatives of ECOWAS, ARAA-Lomé, FAO and Sida. The coordination with major partners continues to work in an excellent manner and is firmly led by FAO in close collaboration with ECOWAS. The first six months of the project implementation (from 1 March to 30 September 2019) focused on the inception phase activities for which a detailed report has been submitted and validated by the steering committee of the project (refer to the inception phase report). The updated and finalized report with related annexes (legal assessment, forest data gap analysis, gender analysis and action plan etc.) have been cleared by the steering committee. The second part of the report covers the period from 1st October to 31 December 2019. During the reporting period three main objectives were identified:finalizing the inception report (including the revised work plan), considering the recommendations from the steering committee; continuing discussions with ECOWAS in order to better define the institutional arrangement for the implementation of the project and put in place the Project Management Unit (PMU). In terms of institutional arrangements strong collaboration has been established among the ECOWAS offices in Abuja, Lomé and Dakar (ECOWAS Gender Development Centre-EGDC). A proposition of a best collaboration scenario (particularly for the implementation of a call for proposals for the community-based projects) has been established and a Letter of Agreement (LoA) signed between FAO and ECOWAS. Administrative works have been finalized in order to put in place a strong Project Management Unit (PMU) to be based at the FAO Subregional Office for West Africa in Dakar and for the International Consultant to support the implementation of community-based forest projects (to be located in the ECOWAS Regional Agency for Agriculture and Food in Lomé).
